intro: Fumaria officinalis var. grandiflora, commonly known as the greater celandine, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It features bright yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer, and its leaves are typically lobed with a distinctive, slightly hairy texture. The plant is characterized by its erect stem and can grow up to 1 meter in height. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and along stream banks. Botanically, it belongs to the Papaveraceae family, which includes other flowering plants known for their medicinal properties.
